citation.article-title: Methanococcus vulcanius sp. nov., a novel hyperthermophilic methanogen isolated from East Pacific Rise, and identification of Methanococcus sp. DSM 4213T as Methanococcus fervens sp. nov.

p.s: Description of Methanococcus vulcanius sp. nov.
Methanococcus vulcanius (vul.ca'ni.us. L. masc. adj. vulcanius referring to Vulcanus, the Roman fire god, and to the place of isolation, the deep-sea hydrothermal vents)
Cells exhibit a tumbling motility by means of three tufts of flagella.
They are cocci (diameter 1-3 μm) and occur singly and in pairs.
Pale-yellow round colonies about 1 mm in diameter formed on 'Phytagel' plates.
Growth occurs between 49 and 89 °C, with an optimum around 80 °C (doubling time 45 min).
Growth occurs between pH 5.25 and 7 with an optimum of approximately pH 6.5 and with NaCl concentrations between 6.25 and 56.25 g l-1 with an optimum of 25 g l-1.
Uses H2 and C2O as energy and carbon sources to produce methane.
Growth is stimulated by selenate, tungstate and yeast extract.
Sulphur is reduced to hydrogen sulphide in the presence of C2O and H2.
Growth is inhibited by chloramphenicol (75 μg ml-1) and rifampicin (50 μg ml-1) but not by streptomycin, penicillin G, kanamycin or ampicillin (all at 200 μg ml-1).
DNA base composition of the type strain is 31 mol%.
G + C (as determined by the thermal denaturation method).
The type strain is Methanococcus vulcanius M7T, which was obtained from a deep-sea hydrothermal vent chimney on the East Pacific Rise (13°N).
Strain M7T has been deposited in the Deutsche Sammlung von Mikroorganismen und Zellkulturen as DSM 12094T.
